bibl.author: Thomas B. Freeman
bibl.title: Thomas B. Freeman to Walt Whitman, 1 February 1877
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

body.p: I received your Book on the war with many many thank. I dont know how I can thank you for your kindness towards me. Can only say that I will allwaysalways entertain the highest regard and esteem for you. The Book is a beautiful specimen and very entertaining to our family and many would like very much to it with you at Camden. I enjoyed my visit so much I would to go to Camden often. Mother and Father are sorry they did not get to see you. I was born the first year of the war so I dont know very much about in your book is about the first book I have read about the war.

having quite a temperance agitation in our Neighborhood there was 250 signed the Pledge but I cannot tell how long they will keep it I hope our present GoverenorGovernor will be our next President. if the Democrats get up a muss I am ready to sholdershoulder my musket I have read some of your book since I got it and it very interesting. I wrote some time ago to Aunt Jennie not knowing her address I first put it in care of John Johnston Street I did not number. I am very busy now I go to day school 5 days of a week at a Bookkeeping school in one week so I havent time to write. I am ing what to say to make a letter but I dont think I make it. We had quite a snow storm this morning
for a short time. I suppose it is totoo cold for you to go to Johnstons and I will have to close in order to this in the mail. So goodbye. Give our respects to all the Johnstons and save a good many for yourself. Give my respects to Frank Post Please accept my sincere thanks for the present you sent me.
